sentences: Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology
[LIST_ITEM] In 1938, a gram of natural cortisone was worth $100 (1938 dollars!)
[LIST_ITEM] For many years ethnobotanists had known that certain plants had been used by primitive peoples as fish poisons, soaps, and shampoos
[LIST_ITEM] Produce foam in water and are called saponins, which are steroids
[LIST_ITEM] Saponin destroys red blood cells on contact
[LIST_ITEM] Causes the fish to be stunned and then float to the surface
[LIST_ITEM] Fish are not poisonous to humans when eaten.
[LIST_ITEM] Some of these saponin-bearing plants were also used by societies as oral contraceptives
[LIST_ITEM] Mexico and Central America, several plants were taken to stop female ovulation
[LIST_ITEM] Matto Grosso Indian women in Brazil took plant products daily to prevent pregnancy
[LIST_ITEM] A company called Syntex was then organized to make steroids from Mexican yams, using the syntheses invented by Marker
[LIST_ITEM] About 66 pounds of fresh yams could yield one pound of diosgenin and two ounces of cortisone
[LIST_ITEM] In the 1960s, a gram of cortisone cost two dollars to produce
[LIST_ITEM] Estradiol is most potent natural estrogen
[LIST_ITEM] Ethinyl group at 17 position made it orally active (EE)
[LIST_ITEM] Older pills had used 3-methyl ester (mestranol) of ethinyl estradiol
[LIST_ITEM] Mestranol will not bind to receptor and must be converted to EE
[LIST_ITEM] Varies with sampling time in the same person
[LIST_ITEM] Same does may cause different side effects in different individuals
[LIST_ITEM] Thrombosis is related to estrogen dose
[LIST_ITEM] Success of EE led to development of ethisterone (oral derivative of testosterone)
[LIST_ITEM] Removal of 19 carbon from ethisterone to form norethindrone
[LIST_ITEM] Changed properties from androgenic to progestogenic
[LIST_ITEM] Progestational derivatives of testosterone are referred to 19-nortestosterone
[LIST_ITEM] Norethindrone can be converted to EE in small amounts
[LIST_ITEM] Also has very weak binding to estrogen receptor
[LIST_ITEM] Serious side effects related to high dose of progestational agents now minimal
[LIST_ITEM] Another compound (Norgestrel) is racemic mixture of d- and l- norgestrel (only d-norgestrel is active)
[LIST_ITEM] Two degradative steps before it expresses progestational properties
[LIST_ITEM] Differs from levonogestrel by a methylene group in 11 position
[LIST_ITEM] Several metabolites contribute to norgestimate activity
[LIST_ITEM] Considered a second generation progestational agent because of metabolite (levonorgestrel)
[LIST_ITEM] Products containing levonorgestrel, norgestimate and other norethindrone family and 30 or 35 ug EE
[LIST_ITEM] Product containing desogestrel or gestodene with 20 or 30 ug EE
[LIST_ITEM] Biologic efficacy of various agents is the same
[LIST_ITEM] Old belief – androgenic progestins caused heart disease
[LIST_ITEM] (actually due to coagulation facilitation by estrogen)
[LIST_ITEM] All are comparable to old products
Formulations ☐ Attempt to reduce side effects, BTB ☐ No real difference noted over monophasic ☐ 7 day pill free ☐ 4 days pill free ☐ 2 days pill free ☐ Estrophasic approach – low early estrogen
[LIST_ITEM] As estrogen rises the SHBG rises
Mechanism of Action ☐ Combined pill is given daily for 3 weeks of 4 ☐ Prevents ovulation

[LIST_ITEM] Hypothalamic ☐ Progestational effect suppresses LH (no surge) ☐ Estrogenic effect suppresses FSH (no dominant follicle) ☐ Even if follicle developed there would be sufficient inhibition to prevent ovulation (minipill) ☐ Purpose of the estrogenic component
[LIST_ITEM] Stability to the endometrium ☐ Prevent irregular shedding (breakthrough bleeding)

[LIST_ITEM] Potentiates the action of progesterone ☐ Allowed reduction in dose of progestational agents ☐ Probably increases intracellular expression of P receptors ☐ Minimal level of estrogen is required to maintain efficacy of combined pill

[LIST_ITEM] Effect of progesterone always exceeds that of estrogen ☐ Endometrium (decidualized, exhausted glands) ☐ Cervical mucous (thick and impervious to sperm) ☐ Tubal function (? Reduction in motility – alteration in tubal fluid)

Efficacy of Oral Contraceptives ☐ Most failures occur because of delay in initiation of next cycle ☐ Allow escape ovulation ☐ Use of placebo pills to avoid “forgetting to restart” is a good idea ☐ Most prevalent problem associated with failure ☐ Vomiting ☐ Diarrhea ☐ Use backup method after bout of gastroenteritis
[LIST_ITEM] Place pill in vagina ☐ .1% failure rate if motivated, 7.6% during first year
David Wagner - Package Designer 28-day menstrual cycle and would encourage women to view the method as “natural.”
[LIST_ITEM] Ovarian and endometrial cancer risk decreases by 40% after 1 year of total OCP pill use and 80% reduction after 10 years of use
[LIST_ITEM] Decreased menstrual cramps, ovulation pain & premenstrual tension
[LIST_ITEM] Can adjust menses for vacations or if conditions require amenorrhea
[LIST_ITEM] Decreased benign ovarian tumors and cysts
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Why is estrogen added to combined OC?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Name the common chemical compounds used in modern OC’s?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] List the major risks of taking OC’s.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What are the benefits of OC’s other than contraception?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the rationale for taking active OC pills for 21 days?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] What is the effect of the combined OC on the endometrium?
[NUMBERED_ITEM] To whom would you not prescribe oral contraceptives? Why?
